Bodybuilding and whey protein powders, are they safe for glucose?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-14-2012 09:39 AM

I want to double down on my exercise and add resistance training to my already cardio exercises. I want to build more muscle mass and get leaner. I am considering using whey protein powder after my workout. Are these safe for someone that needs to watch their glucose? I am 54 and borderline prediabetic and need to watch my glucose (fasting glucose=99 last week)

 

Thanks, Joe

Joe Koppel
Learn by Trail and Error
(Lots of Error)

Re: Bodybuilding and whey protein powders, are they safe for glucose?

Options

‎10-14-2012 09:42 PM

Joe, I would suggest looking at how many carbs per drink serving you're having, looking at the nutritional info on the label.  And then seeing how that affects your glucose readings -- whether it makes your FBG and other readings go up or down, and how much, if at all, and if you're doing enough exercise to use that fuel, or if you want to cut back on it or cut it out altogether.  Some brands may have fewer carbs than others.  Flavored ones would probably have a lot more carbs than the plain ones.  Good luck, and please let us know what you discover!

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

I try and get as much protein as I can from actual food, for a recreational bodybuilder protein powder can be a crutch.

Dx 11/25/2012

A1c 10.8

Currently in the 95-120 range fasted

‎11-29-2012 11:10 AM

A research article I read yesterday, published in Israel and the United States; flat out said that protien from Whey created a beneficial cascasde of peptides and hormones for diabetics in particular.  Going on to say that preworkout routines could be helped by whey protien isolate or even by low fat dairy.

 

I'm going to give this a try.  Sure feels good.  and BG is dramatically and positively affected by wieght training in my personal situation.  

 

Best,

Best, to you
Endo said my case behaves like T1, since about age 50, idiopathic: toxicological, or immune mediated. first dx T2 in 2008 by my GP
Now limiting complications via TSlim pump w/Novalog .... Dexcom

Re: Bodybuilding and whey protein powders, are they safe for glucose?

Options
  • Mark as New

  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎02-22-2013 04:52 PM

Product I see used by several people at my gym as 140 calories and 8 grams carbs per serving (1 scoop).  In moderation those strike me as OK numbers.  The label numbers by % of daily requirements are 52% of protein, 1% of carbs and 17% of cholestrol.  Those numbers suggest that it certainly is a "protein supplement".    I believe whey protein's do help build the muscle mass when in conjuction with the work out program.  Being leaner really requires having less fat and that's probably more cardio and less calories going in.  I eat a protein bar as a post work out that is fairly similar to mixing one of these shakes.  Right now I'm more in a "get leaner" than "build muscle mass" but I don't want to lose any more muscle mass than needed when I'm taking off fat.

Don
Type 2
Diagnosed fall 2008
Diabetes meds: none
A1C 5.0 4/2013

I've tried protein powders after long bike rides.  They tend to dramatically increase my BG.  However, I am T1.  So your reaction might be different.
